body:

If it's not a bug, please remove the template and elaborate the issue in your own words.
-->
## Steps to reproduce
1. Run any command that you could interactively block (e.g. `Get-Command`)
2. Hit `Ctrl+Z`
## Expected behavior

Either:
1. Suspend and background the process OR
2. Do nothing
## Actual behavior

All of PowerShell is suspended and backgrounded at the bash level. 
## Environment data

``` powershell
> $PSVersionTable

CLRVersion
```

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: I'd posit this is the correct behavior for PowerShell on Linux. It is not a built-in shell, so it's obeying the signal appropriately and going back to Bash (your launch shell).

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: @joeyaiello what happens if you've done a chsh?

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
Also, you listed as expected:

> Suspend and background the process OR

It did exactly that.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: This is no longer repro'ing. All I get with Ctrl-Z is a literal `^Z` in my prompt. For some reason .NET Core is ignoring the signal now (since `[Console]::TreatControlCAsInput` is false, this is my guess).

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: Nope, it doesn't look they're intercepting the signals. The change to stop intercepting them is still there, unmodified since May. Hm.

title: Ctrl+Z backgrounds PowerShell and returns to bash
